title: 1 Samuel Chapter 19 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 19 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 19 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 19.

questions.question: Who did Saul command to kill David?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan his son
questions.explanation: Saul spoke to Jonathan his son and to all his servants that they should kill David (1 Samuel 19:1).

questions.question: What did Jonathan do after hearing about Saul's plan to kill David?
options: He told David and advised him to hide
He joined Saul to kill David
questions.correctAnswer: He told David and advised him to hide
questions.explanation: Jonathan told David to take heed to himself and hide in a secret place because Saul sought to kill him (1 Samuel 19:2).

questions.question: What did Jonathan promise to do while David was hiding?
options: Stand beside his father and inform David of Saul's intentions
Help David escape to another country
questions.correctAnswer: Stand beside his father and inform David of Saul's intentions
questions.explanation: Jonathan said he would stand beside his father in the field and communicate about David, then inform David what he saw (1 Samuel 19:3).

questions.question: What reason did Jonathan give Saul to not sin against David?
options: David has not sinned against Saul and did great good
David is beloved by the people
questions.correctAnswer: David has not sinned against Saul and did great good
questions.explanation: Jonathan said David had not sinned against Saul and his works have been very good toward him (1 Samuel 19:4).

questions.question: What did David do when there was war again?
options: Fought the Philistines and slew them with great slaughter
questions.correctAnswer: Fought the Philistines and slew them with great slaughter
questions.explanation: David went out and fought the Philistines, killing many and causing them to flee (1 Samuel 19:8).

questions.question: What happened to Saul as he sat in his house with his javelin in his hand?
options: An evil spirit from the LORD came upon him
questions.correctAnswer: An evil spirit from the LORD came upon him
questions.explanation: The evil spirit from the LORD was upon Saul as he sat with his javelin in his hand (1 Samuel 19:9).

questions.question: How did David escape when Saul tried to strike him with a javelin?
options: He slipped away from Saul's presence
questions.correctAnswer: He slipped away from Saul's presence
questions.explanation: David slipped away from Saul's presence when Saul tried to hit him with the javelin (1 Samuel 19:10).

questions.question: Who warned David about Saul's plan to kill him in the morning?
questions.correctAnswer: Michal, David's wife
questions.explanation: Michal warned David that Saul sent messengers to kill him in the morning (1 Samuel 19:11).

questions.question: How did Michal help David escape from Saul's messengers?
options: She let David down through a window
She hid David in the house
She told Saul David was sick
questions.correctAnswer: She let David down through a window
questions.explanation: Michal let David down through a window so he could flee and escape (1 Samuel 19:12).

questions.question: What did Michal place in David's bed to deceive Saul's messengers?
options: An image with a pillow of goats' hair
questions.correctAnswer: An image with a pillow of goats' hair
questions.explanation: Michal put an image covered with a cloth and a pillow of goats' hair in the bed to deceive the messengers (1 Samuel 19:13).

questions.question: What happened to Saul's messengers when they saw the prophets prophesying at Naioth?
options: The Spirit of God came upon them and they also prophesied
They returned to Saul without David
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of God came upon them and they also prophesied
questions.explanation: Saul's messengers saw the prophets prophesying and the Spirit of God came upon them, causing them also to prophesy (1 Samuel 19:20).

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan agreed with Saul's plan to kill David.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jonathan did not agree; he protected David and spoke good of him to Saul (1 Samuel 19:4-6).

questions.question: True or False: David went to Samuel at Ramah after escaping Saul's attempts on his life.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David fled and came to Samuel at Ramah, telling him all Saul had done (1 Samuel 19:18).

questions.question: True or False: Saul eventually prophesied along with the prophets at Naioth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Saul went to Naioth and the Spirit of God came upon him, causing him to prophesy like the others (1 Samuel 19:23-24).

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Samuel 19:14: 'When Saul sent messengers to take David, she said, ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: He is sick
questions.explanation: Michal told Saul's messengers that David was sick to deceive them (1 Samuel 19:14).

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 19 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 19 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing danger because of their faith. Based on 1 Samuel 19, what biblical virtue can we learn from Jonathan's actions toward David?
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful friendship and protection
questions.explanation: Jonathan showed faithful friendship by warning David of Saul's intent to kill him and protecting him (1 Samuel 19:1-3, 6-7). This teaches us to be loyal and protective of fellow believers.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 19 teach us about prayer and spiritual discernment when facing trials?
options: By seeking God’s guidance and trusting Him
By depending solely on human wisdom
By confronting the enemy with anger
questions.correctAnswer: By seeking God’s guidance and trusting Him
questions.explanation: Jonathan sought to discern Saul's intentions and communicated them to David, showing reliance on wisdom and trust in God during trials (1 Samuel 19:2-3).

questions.question: What lesson about integrity in service to God and others is demonstrated by David’s actions during the war against the Philistines?
options: Diligent and courageous service honors God
questions.correctAnswer: Diligent and courageous service honors God
questions.explanation: David continued to serve faithfully and fought bravely against the Philistines, demonstrating integrity in his work even amid danger (1 Samuel 19:8).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear due to threats against their life. Based on 1 Samuel 19, what biblical truth encourages perseverance?
options: Trust in God's protection and seek wise counsel
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's protection and seek wise counsel
questions.explanation: David trusted God’s protection and received help from Jonathan and Michal, showing the importance of faith and wise help in adversity (1 Samuel 19:2, 11-12, 18).

questions.question: How does Michal’s help to David illustrate biblical principles of love and sacrifice within marriage?
options: She risked her own safety to protect her husband
She abandoned David to save herself
questions.correctAnswer: She risked her own safety to protect her husband
questions.explanation: Michal helped David escape by letting him down through a window and deceiving Saul’s messengers, demonstrating sacrificial love and protection in marriage (1 Samuel 19:11-16).

questions.question: What practical Christian truth about honesty and deception can we learn from Michal’s actions?
options: Sometimes deception is used to preserve life and serve a higher good
Deception is always wrong no matter what
questions.correctAnswer: Sometimes deception is used to preserve life and serve a higher good
questions.explanation: Michal’s use of a false image to protect David shows that in extreme situations, deception may be used to preserve life and serve God’s purposes (1 Samuel 19:13-16, 17).

questions.question: How does Saul’s repeated sending of messengers to capture David teach about God’s power over evil intentions?
options: God can turn the hearts of enemies and use their plans for His purposes
One should rely on their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: God can turn the hearts of enemies and use their plans for His purposes
questions.explanation: Saul’s messengers were overcome by the Spirit of God and began prophesying, showing God’s power over human schemes (1 Samuel 19:20-21).

questions.question: What does Saul’s experience of prophesying teach about humility and God’s discipline?
options: God can humble even the proud and call them to repentance
questions.correctAnswer: God can humble even the proud and call them to repentance
questions.explanation: Saul was overcome by the Spirit and prophesied naked, illustrating God’s way of humbling him and showing His control over all people (1 Samuel 19:23-24).

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan convinced Saul not to kill David because David had done no wrong against Saul.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jonathan reminded Saul that David had been loyal and had done good by killing the Philistine, and therefore should not be slain (1 Samuel 19:4-6).

questions.question: True or False: David fled from Saul’s attempts to kill him without any help or warning from others.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David was warned by Jonathan and Michal, who helped him escape, showing the importance of fellowship and support in trials (1 Samuel 19:2, 11-12).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When Saul’s messengers saw the company of prophets prophesying, the Spirit of God was upon them and they also ________.
questions.correctAnswer: prophesied
questions.explanation: The Spirit of God came upon Saul’s messengers and they too began prophesying, demonstrating God’s power over human plans (1 Samuel 19:20).

questions.question: How does the story of David’s escape teach us about trusting God’s deliverance and using wisdom in trials?
options: Trust God and seek practical help from others
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God and seek practical help from others
questions.explanation: David trusted God’s protection and received help from Jonathan and Michal, illustrating faith combined with wise action (1 Samuel 19:2-3, 11-12, 18).

questions.question: What lesson about church fellowship and spiritual leadership is shown when Samuel and David dwell together at Naioth?
options: Spiritual community provides strength and protection
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual community provides strength and protection
questions.explanation: David and Samuel dwelling in Naioth, among the prophets, shows the strength found in godly fellowship and leadership (1 Samuel 19:18-19).

questions.question: What does Jonathan’s intercession for David teach about reconciliation and love for neighbors?
options: Advocate for others even when it is difficult
questions.correctAnswer: Advocate for others even when it is difficult
questions.explanation: Jonathan spoke to Saul to prevent him from sinning against David, showing love and desire for reconciliation (1 Samuel 19:4-6).

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 19 teach us about humility in leadership through Saul’s experience?
options: Leaders must submit to God’s authority and discipline
Pride is a sign of strength
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must submit to God’s authority and discipline
questions.explanation: Saul’s being overcome by the Spirit and prophesying naked shows God's authority over leaders and the need for humility (1 Samuel 19:23-24).

questions.question: What principle about perseverance through trials can be drawn from David’s continued fighting against the Philistines despite Saul’s threats?
options: Remain faithful and diligent in God’s work despite opposition
questions.correctAnswer: Remain faithful and diligent in God’s work despite opposition
questions.explanation: David fought and won battles against the Philistines even while Saul sought his life, teaching perseverance and faithfulness (1 Samuel 19:8-10).

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 19 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 19.

questions.question: What is the primary reason Jonathan pleaded with his father Saul regarding David?
options: David had been loyal and had not sinned against Saul
David was a better warrior than Saul
Jonathan wanted to take David's place as king
questions.correctAnswer: David had been loyal and had not sinned against Saul
questions.explanation: Jonathan reminded Saul that David had done good by risking his life for Israel and had not sinned against Saul (1 Samuel 19:4-5).

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 19:9 illustrate the motif of divine intervention in the conflict between Saul and David?
options: An evil spirit from the LORD came upon Saul, influencing his actions
David used magic to protect himself
Jonathan prayed to God to save David
Saul was possessed by a foreign god
questions.correctAnswer: An evil spirit from the LORD came upon Saul, influencing his actions
questions.explanation: The passage states that an evil spirit from the LORD came upon Saul, indicating divine involvement in Saul’s hostility (1 Samuel 19:9).

questions.question: In what way does Michal's deception of Saul in 1 Samuel 19 reflect ancient Near Eastern cultural practices of protection within the household?
options: She used a household idol and goats’ hair to simulate David’s presence
She hid David in a secret chamber beneath the house
She bribed Saul’s servants to look the other way
She fled with David to a neighboring tribe
questions.correctAnswer: She used a household idol and goats’ hair to simulate David’s presence
questions.explanation: Michal placed an image and goats’ hair on the bed to deceive Saul’s messengers, a tactic reflecting household protective measures (1 Samuel 19:13-16).

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the repeated sending of Saul's messengers who then prophesy at Naioth?
options: Repetition to emphasize the irresistible power of the Spirit
Irony in Saul’s failure to capture David
questions.correctAnswer: Repetition to emphasize the irresistible power of the Spirit
questions.explanation: The repeated sending of messengers who end up prophesying highlights the Spirit’s overpowering influence (1 Samuel 19:20-21).

questions.question: How does Saul's behavior at the end of the chapter, where he prophesies and lies naked, function theologically in the narrative?
options: It symbolizes his loss of royal dignity and submission to God's Spirit
It shows his complete rejection of God
It is a sign of his insanity unrelated to divine influence
It indicates his transformation into a prophet like Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes his loss of royal dignity and submission to God's Spirit
questions.explanation: Saul’s stripping and prophesying represent a dramatic reversal, showing divine control over him despite his hostility (1 Samuel 19:23-24).

questions.question: Which theme common to the Davidic narrative is foreshadowed by Jonathan’s protective actions toward David?
options: The covenantal friendship and loyalty between David and Jonathan
The rejection of Saul as king
The establishment of Jerusalem as the capital
questions.correctAnswer: The covenantal friendship and loyalty between David and Jonathan
questions.explanation: Jonathan’s warning and protection foreshadow the strong covenantal bond between him and David (1 Samuel 19:1-3).

questions.question: What does the Hebrew term translated as 'evil spirit' in 1 Samuel 19:9 imply about divine sovereignty in this context?
options: That God permits or sends harmful spirits to accomplish His purposes
That Saul was possessed by a foreign demon
That Saul’s mental illness was misunderstood
That Saul was cursed by a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: That God permits or sends harmful spirits to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates that Yahweh sovereignly allowed an evil spirit to come upon Saul to fulfill divine judgment (1 Samuel 19:9).

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan’s intervention leads Saul to swear that David would not be killed at that time.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Saul hearkened to Jonathan and swore that David should not be slain (1 Samuel 19:6).

questions.question: What is the significance of David fleeing to Samuel and dwelling in Naioth according to ancient Israelite prophetic tradition?
options: It places David within the prophetic community, symbolizing divine protection
It shows David abandoning his royal ambitions
It is a withdrawal from political conflict
It indicates David’s rejection of Saul’s kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: It places David within the prophetic community, symbolizing divine protection
questions.explanation: David’s refuge at Naioth with Samuel situates him within the prophetic tradition, where the Spirit protects him (1 Samuel 19:18-19).

questions.question: How does the narrative technique used in 1 Samuel 19, involving Saul’s repeated attempts to kill David and his failure, serve the overall plot structure?
options: It builds tension and highlights God’s protection over David
questions.correctAnswer: It builds tension and highlights God’s protection over David
questions.explanation: Saul’s repeated but failed attempts emphasize divine preservation of David and increase narrative suspense (1 Samuel 19:10-12, 20-21).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Michal said to Saul, 'He said unto me, Let me go; why should I _____?'
questions.correctAnswer: kill thee
questions.explanation: Michal told Saul that David said, 'Let me go; why should I kill thee?' (1 Samuel 19:17).

questions.question: What cultural or historical insight can be drawn from Saul’s use of a javelin to attempt to kill David in the house?
options: A javelin was a common weapon signifying close royal authority and aggression
Javelins were only used in battlefield settings
The javelin was a symbol of peace
Saul’s use of a javelin indicated a formal duel
questions.correctAnswer: A javelin was a common weapon signifying close royal authority and aggression
questions.explanation: The javelin as a handheld weapon in the house shows Saul’s direct personal aggression toward David (1 Samuel 19:9-10).

questions.question: How does the episode of Saul prophesying naked (1 Samuel 19:24) function as a form of irony within the narrative?
options: It is ironic that Saul, who sought to kill God’s anointed, becomes a prophet himself
It shows Saul’s triumph over the prophets
It indicates that Saul has replaced Samuel as the leader
It reveals Saul’s secret alliance with David
questions.correctAnswer: It is ironic that Saul, who sought to kill God’s anointed, becomes a prophet himself
questions.explanation: The irony is that Saul, opposed to David, is overtaken by the Spirit and prophesies like the prophets he opposed (1 Samuel 19:24).

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the theme of loyalty and protection found in Jonathan’s relationship with David?
options: John 15:13, about the greatest love laying down one’s life for friends
Revelation 21:4, about new heaven and earth
questions.correctAnswer: John 15:13, about the greatest love laying down one’s life for friends
questions.explanation: Jonathan’s protective loyalty prefigures Jesus’ teaching on love and sacrifice in John 15:13.

questions.question: What does the motif of ‘prophesying’ in this chapter suggest about the role of the Spirit in Israel’s leadership?
options: The Spirit can overturn human intentions and empower even Saul’s messengers
Prophesying was a sign of political rebellion
The Spirit was absent from Saul’s reign
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit can overturn human intentions and empower even Saul’s messengers
questions.explanation: The Spirit coming upon Saul’s messengers to prophesy shows divine control over human plans (1 Samuel 19:20-23).

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 19 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 19 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What motivated Jonathan to warn David about Saul's intention to kill him?
options: Jonathan wanted to seize the throne
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan delighted much in David
questions.explanation: Jonathan's love and delight in David motivated him to warn him of Saul's intent to kill him, showing covenantal loyalty and love (1 Samuel 19:2). This reflects God's command to love others (Leviticus 19:18), and Christ's teaching on loving one's neighbor (Matthew 22:39).

questions.question: How did Jonathan intercede for David before Saul?
options: He spoke good of David and reminded Saul of his past deeds
questions.correctAnswer: He spoke good of David and reminded Saul of his past deeds
questions.explanation: Jonathan's intercession was grounded in truth and appeal to Saul's reason, highlighting David's faithful service and God's salvation through him, demonstrating the biblical principle of advocacy (1 Samuel 19:4-5). This echoes intercessory prayer in Scripture (Romans 8:34) and Christ as our advocate (1 John 2:1).

questions.question: What was Saul's response to Jonathan's plea?
options: Saul swore that David would not be slain
questions.correctAnswer: Saul swore that David would not be slain
questions.explanation: Saul hearkened to Jonathan and swore by the LORD that David would not be killed, showing his temporary submission to God's authority (1 Samuel 19:6). This reflects God's covenant faithfulness and the power of oaths in Scripture (Numbers 30:2, Hebrews 6:16-18).

questions.question: Despite Saul's oath, what continued to happen between Saul and David?
options: Saul's evil spirit troubled him, and he sought to kill David again
questions.correctAnswer: Saul's evil spirit troubled him, and he sought to kill David again
questions.explanation: Saul was tormented by an evil spirit from the LORD and tried to kill David with a javelin, showing human sinfulness and God's sovereign permission of spiritual opposition (1 Samuel 19:9-10). This aligns with Scripture's teaching on spiritual warfare (Ephesians 6:12) and God's judgment (Romans 1:18-28).

questions.question: How did Michal help David escape Saul's plan to kill him?
options: She let him down through a window and deceived Saul with an image
She fled with David to another city
She hid David in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: She let him down through a window and deceived Saul with an image
questions.explanation: Michal's actions saved David by letting him down through a window and using a fake image to deceive Saul's messengers, illustrating human agency in God's providence (1 Samuel 19:12-16). This demonstrates God's use of human wisdom and courage (Proverbs 21:1, Exodus 1:15-21).

questions.question: What reason did Michal give Saul for David's absence?
options: She said David was with Samuel
She said David was at war
questions.correctAnswer: She said David was sick
questions.explanation: Michal told Saul that David was sick, a lie to protect him, showing the tension between loyalty to family and obedience to authority (1 Samuel 19:14). This reflects the biblical theme of protecting the innocent (Proverbs 24:11-12) and complex moral decisions in Scripture (Acts 5:29).

questions.question: After David fled, where did he go and with whom did he dwell?
options: He went to Samuel and dwelt in Naioth
He fled to the wilderness alone
He returned to his own house
questions.correctAnswer: He went to Samuel and dwelt in Naioth
questions.explanation: David fled to Samuel and they dwelt in Naioth, indicating prophetic protection and God's provision through His servants (1 Samuel 19:18). This highlights the role of the prophetic community as a refuge (Psalm 91:1-2, Isaiah 8:13).

questions.question: What happened to Saul's messengers when they came to capture David at Naioth?
options: They were overcome by the Spirit of God and began to prophesy
questions.correctAnswer: They were overcome by the Spirit of God and began to prophesy
questions.explanation: Saul's messengers were filled with the Spirit of God and prophesied, demonstrating God's sovereign control and the power of the Holy Spirit to transform even enemies (1 Samuel 19:20). This parallels the Spirit's work in the early Church (Acts 2:4) and Old Testament prophecy (Joel 2:28).

questions.question: How did Saul respond after his messengers prophesied at Naioth?
options: He sent more messengers, who also prophesied, and then went himself and prophesied
questions.correctAnswer: He sent more messengers, who also prophesied, and then went himself and prophesied
questions.explanation: Saul's repeated sending of messengers, all of whom prophesied, followed by his own prophesying, shows God's sovereign intervention and judgment on Saul's disobedience (1 Samuel 19:21-23). This illustrates God's power over human plans (Proverbs 19:21) and the Spirit's work (Isaiah 61:1).

questions.question: What unusual behavior did Saul exhibit when he came to Naioth?
options: He stripped off his clothes and prophesied, lying naked all day and night
He built an altar to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He stripped off his clothes and prophesied, lying naked all day and night
questions.explanation: Saul's stripping and prophesying naked reflect divine judgment and humiliation, signifying loss of kingship and prophetic madness (1 Samuel 19:24). This foreshadows God's discipline of sin (Psalm 51:17, Isaiah 20:2-4) and serves as a warning about rebellion against God (Hebrews 12:6).

questions.question: What theological theme is evident in the repeated attempts of Saul to kill David and God's protection over David?
options: God's sovereign preservation of His anointed
The divine endorsement of Saul's anger
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign preservation of His anointed
questions.explanation: The chapter demonstrates God's sovereign protection over David, His chosen anointed king, despite human opposition, illustrating divine election and providence (1 Samuel 19:1-24). This aligns with God's promises to protect His servants (Psalm 34:7, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: How does the presence of the Spirit of God upon Saul's messengers and Saul himself relate to Pneumatology?
options: It shows the Spirit's sovereign and sometimes judgmental work in the Old Testament
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the Spirit's sovereign and sometimes judgmental work in the Old Testament
questions.explanation: The Spirit's coming upon Saul and his messengers to prophesy reveals the Spirit's sovereign activity, including judgment and correction, in the OT era (1 Samuel 19:20-24). This fits with the Spirit's role in sanctification and revelation (John 16:8, Ezekiel 36:27).

questions.question: What Christological theme can be drawn from Jonathan's protecting of David despite Saul's hatred?
options: Foreshadowing of Christ's intercession and friendship
questions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing of Christ's intercession and friendship
questions.explanation: Jonathan's loyal protection of David prefigures Christ's role as intercessor and friend to sinners, demonstrating grace and covenant love (1 Samuel 19:2-7). Christ intercedes for us (Romans 8:34) and calls us friends (John 15:15).

questions.question: How does this chapter illustrate the biblical doctrine of sin and its consequences?
options: Saul's jealousy and disobedience lead to spiritual torment and loss of kingly authority
David sins and is punished immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Saul's jealousy and disobedience lead to spiritual torment and loss of kingly authority
questions.explanation: Saul's sinful jealousy results in an evil spirit tormenting him and eventual loss of authority, teaching that sin leads to judgment and downfall (1 Samuel 19:9-24). This aligns with biblical warnings about sin's consequences (Romans 1:18-32, Galatians 6:7).

questions.question: What does Michal's protection of David teach about human responsibility amidst divine providence?
options: God often uses human agency and courage to fulfill His plans
Only prophets can protect God's anointed
Women are excluded from divine plans
questions.correctAnswer: God often uses human agency and courage to fulfill His plans
questions.explanation: Michal's courageous act to save David shows that humans are instruments of God's providence, consistent with biblical teaching on human responsibility (1 Samuel 19:11-17, Exodus 1:15-21). Scripture affirms cooperation with God's will (Philippians 2:12-13).

questions.question: What does the episode of Saul prophesying naked suggest about divine judgment and kingship?
options: It symbolizes Saul's humiliation and loss of divine favor
It confirms Saul as the rightful king forever
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Saul's humiliation and loss of divine favor
questions.explanation: Saul's naked prophesying symbolizes divine judgment and public humiliation, indicating his rejection as king by God (1 Samuel 19:24). This reflects the biblical pattern where sin leads to loss of honor and blessing (Isaiah 20:2-4, Psalm 75:7).
